title: 104_s1738
content: The Act may be cited as the "Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Accessibility and Partnership Act of 1996". The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, located on the Minnesota-Ontario border, is a unique Federal wilderness area dedicated to public access for motorized and nonmotorized recreational activities. Intergovernmental cooperation is essential for land management decisions involving State, local, and tribal governments. The national interest is served by improving the management and protection of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, allowing innovative management partnerships, and ensuring public access through nonmotorized and limited motorized means. SEC. 3. MANAGEMENT CHANGES. The use of motorboats in specific lakes is being amended under Public Law 95-495. Lac La Croix in Saint Louis County, Basswood, Birch, and Saganaga Lakes in Lake County are affected by the changes. Sea Gull Lake is also mentioned in the law. Sea Gull Lake is being amended under Public Law 95-495, with changes to motorboat regulations. The amendments include removing specific portions and defining guests who have access to the lake. Amendment to Public Law 95-495 allows motorized vehicles for portages between Moose Lake chain, Fall Lake, Lake Vermilion, and Basswood Lake. SEC. 4. PLANNING AND MANAGEMENT COUNCIL. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council is established to develop and monitor a management plan for the wilderness. It consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including the Under Secretary for Natural Resources and Environment of the Department of Agriculture. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council is established with 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from various departments and counties in Minnesota. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from different departments and counties in Minnesota. The council includes members from the legislative district containing part of the wilderness, an elected official from the Native American community representing the 1854 Treaty Authority, and may establish advisory councils for consultation with various organizations. A majority of council members constitutes a quorum. Advisory councils cannot receive funding from the Act. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council shall elect a chairperson from among its members, who can serve up to 2 terms of 2 years each. Meetings will be called by the chairperson or a majority of council members. The Council may appoint staff and procure temporary services as needed. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services, personnel, information, and services from the Secretary, and information and services from other federal agencies on a reimbursable basis. The Governor of Minnesota may also provide support on a reimbursable basis. The Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council may request personnel and information from Minnesota on a reimbursable basis. The Council cannot issue subpoenas. Meetings must be open to the public with timely public notice published in local newspapers. Public participation in meetings of the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness Intergovernmental Council allows interested persons to give oral or written statements. Minutes must be kept with details of attendees, proceedings, discussions, and conclusions. The administrative record, including minutes, is available for public inspection. The administrative record of each meeting, along with related documents, must be available for public inspection. The Council must consider new information from agencies or advisory bodies, allowing interested parties to respond before final action is taken on management measures. The Council members serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses while performing services. The Secretary makes funding available from the Forest Service's appropriations for the fiscal year. The Council members serve without pay and are allowed travel expenses while performing services. The Secretary shall make available amounts requested by the Council, not exceeding $150,000 for the fiscal year. The Council will terminate 10 years after the enactment of this subsection. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. Section 20 of Public Law 95-495 is amended to read as follows: "SEC. 20. MANAGEMENT PLAN." The Council must submit a comprehensive management plan for the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness within 3 years of enactment. A preliminary report outlining the plan development process is due within 1 year of the Council's first meeting. The plan should address year-round visitation and other relevant issues. The Council must develop a management plan for the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, focusing on year-round visitation, visitor distribution, and education. The plan should address permit systems, visitor discrepancies, and special policies for commercial use, while complying with environmental laws and consulting regularly with relevant stakeholders. The Council must consult with various agencies and organizations, hold public meetings, and may not consider removing wilderness designation or allowing certain activities like mining or logging. The Council submits the plan to the Secretary and Governor of Minnesota for review. The Governor can comment within 60 days, and the Secretary must approve or disapprove within 90 days, considering specific criteria. The Secretary reviews the plan considering public participation, assurances from State and local officials, regulatory and financial tools, oversight provisions by the Council, and consistency with Federal law. If disapproved, notification is given. The Secretary reviews the plan, considering public participation, assurances from officials, regulatory tools, oversight provisions, and consistency with Federal law. If disapproved, the Secretary notifies the Council with reasons and recommendations for revision. The Council must revise and resubmit the plan within 60 days, and the Secretary must approve or disapprove the revised plan within 30 days. The Council reviews and monitors the implementation of the plan, with the ability to modify it after public comment and approval by the Secretary if necessary. Before plan approval, the Council collaborates with governmental entities to minimize adverse impacts. The Secretary is restricted from issuing regulations related to the Boundary during this interim period. The Secretary is prohibited from issuing regulations regarding the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness, except for routine business and emergency regulations. State and local jurisdiction in Minnesota is not affected by this Act.
